comment._content: We call this a pier in England

comment.author: 9762497@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/alandenney] 
I think that jetty is the word used on the caption printed on the card hence the flickr caption.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: On a map from 1973, this structure is named "jetty", the pier is at the harbour. (source: www.old-maps.co.uk/) The jetty was designed by Eugenius Birch in 1856 (see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Margate). In 1978, it was badly damaged by a storm and removed 1979-1998, see www.margatelocalhistory.co.uk/Pictures/Pictures-Storms.ht...

comment.author: 25825879@N05
comment._content: An English person seeing this image will tell you this is a pier, one of the hundreds of seaside piers built around our coast by the Victorians. It was apparently named "The Jetty" in the 1850s to distinguish it from the pre-existing Margate Pier Harbour wall - http://www.piers.org.uk/pierpages/NPSmargate.html

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alandenney] Agreed (but your link is not working, must be www.piers.org.uk/pierpages/NPSmargate.html. And it seems, that some remains existed until 1998, but were removed then completely, see www.margatelocalhistory.co.uk/Pictures/Pictures-Storms.ht...)
